title: 115_hr3339
content: The Act titled "Promoting Transparency in Trade Act" requires the publication of texts related to negotiating rounds. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the publication of proposed and considered texts for each negotiating round on a publicly available website. Additionally, procedural disapproval resolution is updated to include publication of texts. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the publication of proposed and considered texts for each negotiating round on a publicly available website. This includes the ability to notify, consult, or publish texts with respect to negotiations. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the President to publish texts related to negotiations or face consequences under section 105(a)(1)(E). The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the President to publish texts related to negotiations or face consequences under section 105(a)(1)(E). Additionally, definitions in the Act are updated to include the term "considered text" referring to proposals considered during negotiating rounds. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the publication of negotiating proposals without regard to confidentiality, including identification of supporting parties. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the publication of negotiating proposals without regard to confidentiality, including identification of supporting parties. This includes defining terms such as "negotiating round" and "proposed United States text" for clarity in the agreement negotiations. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to appoint a Chief Transparency Officer to ensure transparency in the activities of the Office of the Trade Representative, including trade negotiations, without any conflicts of interest.
